g.text: identifying it uniquely. To determine this phase, we performed
up to 150 GPa at room temperature. We explored several can-
didate structures, inspired from other ice and ﬁlled-ice phases.
Along the simulations of MH-III at high pressures, we observed
changes of the H-bonded network during a fewdynamical events.
By following this route, we found a structure, the MH-IV phase,
shown in Fig. 2, which becomes more stable than MH-III around
). This structure reproduces all of the fea-
tures of our Raman study and previous X-ray diffraction data
The MH-IV phase has an orthorhombic crystal cell based on
skeleton with the same stoichiometry as MH-III, i.e.,
ratio. This indicates that the MH-III
IV transition can happen at constant chemical potential, without
need of providing or removing atoms. The space group of MH-
62) where oxygen and carbon atoms occupy
4c Wyckoff sites (Table 1). MH-IV contains ordered methane
molecules and differs from MH-III where both ice network and
methane ordering are concerned. The water network of MH-IV
is much closer to ice I
than that of the MH-III phase, which
is substantiated by a quantitative estimate of the topological
distance (i.e., relying on the reduced coordinates) between the
oxygen atoms of those 2 hydrate phases and ice I
MH-III there are 4-, 6-, and 8-fold water rings while in MH-IV
the H-bonded water network is composed of corrugated (
sheets of edge-sharing 6-member rings of water molecules which

seen in the 3 crystal planes. O atoms are in red, C atoms in black, and H
atoms in light gray. Note in
panel that methane molecules have a
In MH-IV, the carbon atoms and a C–Hbond in each methane
conﬁgurations that differ by a rotation of
arrangement, all C–H bonds of the methane point toward the
hexagonal channels formed by the host
reducing repulsive methane–water interactions. Our optimized
lattice parameters at 50 GPa for the MH-IV structure agree well
with those proposed at the same pressure in ref. 14 for the hypo-
thetical (at the time) orthorhombic structure referred to as post
MH-IV transition, the major change concerns
which decreases by about 3.2% due to the particular methane
ordering along this axis (Table 1). In addition, Fig. 3
the MH-IV structure quantitatively reproduces the location and
intensity ratios of the main peaks in the X-ray diffraction data
fromref. 15, which is a strong indication that the atomic positions
of the C and O atoms of the simulated MH-IV structure match
the experimental ones. The structural properties of MH-IV
reproduce the whole information about the hypothetical phase
that was invoked by Hirai and coworkers (13–16). We believe
that such an excellent agreement is not accidental and that the
MH-IVstructure we propose corresponds to the unsolved one as
K as a function of pressure,
obtained fromstatic calculations. Accordingly, the MH-IVstruc-
ture becomes more stable than MH-III for pressures greater
30 GPa. The transition pressure as established experi-
mentally (14) is 40 GPa. Such a difference can be attributed to
several factors: First, the chosen approximation to the exchange-
correlation energy within the DFT; second, the fact that static
energy calculations take into account neither thermal nor quan-
tum effects; and last but not least, it can also be due to
kinetic hindrance. Therefore, from now on we adopt 40
as the transition pressure. Upon further compression, the free
enthalpy difference grows up to 400 meV per methane molecule
at 150 GPa. Its trend shows that the stability of the MH-IV
phase, with smaller volume, increases steadily with pressure.
The transition from MH-III to MH-IV is accompanied by the
formation of 6-fold water rings, at the expense of 4- and 8-
fold ones. As pressure increases and hydrogen bonds contract,
causes a fast augmentation of the gap between the corre-
sponding internal energies, which consistently keeps rising with
The phase transition from MH-III to MH-IV can also be
detected by looking into the behavior of the vibration modes
as a function of the increasing pressure. In the MH-III struc-
ture, the methane molecules undergo an increasing distortion
from tetrahedral symmetry upon compression (11); at
angle diminishes while another widens by
loss of degeneracy of methane stretching and bending modes.
After the transition to MH-IV, the
almost recover their tetrahedral value. Fig. 1 presents the com-
stretching mode frequencies in MH-III and MH-IV,
compared with those obtained through Raman spectroscopy.
for by the computed trends for MH-III below 30 GPa and
by those calculated for the MH-IV structure above this pres-
sure threshold. The experimental full width at half maximum
(FWHM) of the 2 methane stretching modes changes slope
). Scrutinizing the outcomes of the sim-
ulations, the methane molecules deviate from the tetrahedral
